verses.text: My child, have you sinned? Do not do it again; instead, pray for forgiveness for your past actions.
verses.comment: The emphasis on confessing and forsaking sin echoes Proverbs 28:13 and the call in 1 John 1:9 to confession and repentance, showing the biblical pattern for ongoing forgiveness.

verses.text: Escape from sin as if from a snake; for if you come near, its bite is sure. Its teeth are the teeth of a lion, destroying the lives of men.
verses.comment: Sin is depicted as deadly and predatory, a warning to avoid even its proximity, recalling wisdom literature's imagery and the danger of repeated sin.

verses.text: All lawlessness is like a two-edged sword; its wounds are beyond healing.
verses.comment: Sin's destructive nature is likened to a sword that kills physically and spiritually. The reference can spiritually point ahead to the cleansing but also division brought by God’s Word in Hebrews 4:12.

verses.text: Terror and violence will never depart from the house of the arrogant.
verses.comment: Pride is linked to strife and turmoil; humility is repeatedly praised in both Testaments as essential for peace with God and neighbor.

verses.text: Whoever accepts correction will be counted as wise, and in their house wisdom will find a resting place.
verses.comment: Wisdom seeks those willing to change; openness to correction is a constant biblical mark of godliness. Wisdom's personification hints at Divine Wisdom incarnate in Christ (see John 1:1, 1 Cor. 1:24).

verses.text: A wise person among the people will be honored, and those who speak well are welcomed.
verses.comment: Speech demonstrates character; Jesus emphasized that words reveal the heart (Matt. 12:34), a principle rooted in wisdom tradition.

verses.text: The senseless use of words is avoided by the wise; but the foolish person pours out foolish talk.
verses.comment: The value of silence and discretion is central to biblical wisdom. Carefully chosen speech is expected of those growing in holiness.

verses.text: A thief is preferable to one who constantly lies; both, however, will inherit destruction.
verses.comment: Both are condemned, but lying is seen as especially damaging. The spiritual implications connect to the commandment against false witness and Christ as the Truth (John 14:6).

verses.text: The lives of the arrogant will collapse suddenly, just as their prideful plans vanish.
verses.comment: Pride leads to ruin, echoing the warning in Proverbs and Psalms. Humility protects one's soul.

verses.text: A person who teaches sinners is like one building a house with mud and straw.
verses.comment: Instruction must be based on truth and virtue, or it crumbles; Jesus Himself spoke of building on a firm foundation (Matt. 7:26-27).

verses.text: The gathering of lawless people is like a pile of burning wood; their end is a flame of fire.
verses.comment: Judgment upon the wicked is portrayed using fire imagery, with ultimate eschatological fulfillment underscored by Jesus’ teaching in Matthew 13.

verses.text: The way of sinners is paved smoothly, but it leads directly to ruin.
verses.comment: The fleeting ease of sin contrasts with its inevitable destruction; spiritual discernment is needed to see beyond immediate comfort.

verses.text: Whoever keeps the law controls their own desires; the fulfillment begins with fearing the Lord.
verses.comment: True self-control flows from obedience to God’s commands, corresponding with Christ’s teaching on love and obedience.

verses.text: Perfect understanding comes from wisdom; the wise hear and grow even more wise.
verses.comment: Wisdom grows by listening, not resisting correction. Spiritual progress requires docility and humility.

verses.text: One who learns from wise people will receive knowledge; whoever associates with fools will become like them.
verses.comment: The power of community shapes moral character; the company one keeps matters for spiritual growth.

verses.text: All animals flee the wild lion; so also do sinners tremble before the person filled with wisdom.
verses.comment: True wisdom brings a divine authority; even evil shrinks before holiness, prefiguring Christ’s authority over evil spirits.

verses.text: A friend who jokes when you are hurting is like one who wounds you rather than heals.
verses.comment: Compassion is a measure of genuine friendship, mirroring Christ’s empathy.

verses.text: Harsh words spoken at the wrong time are as out of place as music at a funeral.
verses.comment: Discernment in speech and action is integral to wisdom; timing matters for healing and encouragement.

verses.text: Teaching to fools is like gluing a broken clay pot; so is advice that cannot be received.
verses.comment: There is a spiritual lesson in prudent evangelization: some hearts require preparation before truth can dwell.

verses.text: Speaking to those without understanding is like awakening someone from deep sleep; they will ask, 'What has been said?'
verses.comment: Spiritual receptivity is needed for wisdom; Jesus often said, 'He who has ears, let him hear' (Matt. 13:9).

verses.text: Weeping over the dead lasts for a day or two, but sorrow over a fool endures all one's life.
verses.comment: The persistent pain of folly exceeds brief mourning; this displays the lasting consequences of sin and lack of wisdom.

verses.text: Disgrace for the dead is a cause for tears, but disgrace for a fool and a wicked person is worse than death.
verses.comment: Spiritual death is worse than physical death; Christ’s resurrection answers both bodily and spiritual corruption.

verses.text: It is easier to comfort the dead than to change the heart of a fool.
verses.comment: Foolishness resists repentance; only by God's grace can hearts be changed, foreshadowing New Testament teaching on regeneration.

verses.text: The mourning of the dead lasts seven days, but for the foolish and the wicked, it continues a lifetime.
verses.comment: Traditional mourning practices intersect with the lasting sorrow caused by sin and folly; biblical history confirms periods of mourning (Gen. 50:10).

verses.text: Do not speak long among fools, and do not frequent those without understanding.
verses.comment: Saintly wisdom includes prudent protection from corrupting influence, echoing the biblical call to holiness.

verses.text: Do not listen to useless talk; for from empty words great evil comes.
verses.comment: Speech shapes the soul; Christ warns of accountability for every careless word, deepening the spiritual weight of speech.

verses.text: The heart of fools is in their mouth, but the mouth of the wise is in their heart.
verses.comment: True wisdom is internal and flows out, whereas folly speaks without reflection; Christ teaches that the mouth reveals the heart.

verses.text: When an ungodly person curses their adversary, they are really cursing themselves.
verses.comment: Cursing others ultimately rebounds on the soul; spiritual maturity, as Christ taught, entails blessing rather than condemning adversaries.
